thread.title: Blue Jays claim switch pitcher Pat Venditte
thread.title_full: Blue Jays claim switch pitcher Pat Venditte | Toronto Star

author: Mark Zwolinski
title: Blue Jays claim switch pitcher Pat Venditte
text:
Photos View photos zoom The Blue Jays claimed one of the more interesting pitchers in baseball, just hours before they took the field for Game 3 of the American League Championship Series.
Toronto claimed pitcher Pat Venditte from the Oakland A’s, landing a pitcher who is best known for being a successful, ambidextrous thrower.
Venditte, 30, from Omaha, Neb., made his major league debut with Oakland this season after eight minor league seasons. He was 2-2 with the A’s, posting a 4.40 ERA in 26 relief appearances.
He was the first pitcher to throw with either arm to appear in a major-league game since Greg Harris in 1995. He had to indicate whether he would pitch left- or right-handed before the batter came to the plate. Venditte was not allow to pitch with his other arm during the at-bat.
Venditte was drafted in the 20th round by the Yankees in 2008.
Toronto optioned infielder Darwin Barnery for assignment to make room on the 40-man roster for Venditte. He’s not eligible for post-season play.
